thread.title: Homes without power after wild winds and storms across South Australia | The
thread.title_full: Homes without power after wild winds and storms across South Australia | The Advertiser

title: Homes without power after wild winds and storms across South Australia | The
text:
CONDITIONS have eased in Adelaide but severe weather will continue in other parts of the state today, with 2000 homes still without power.
SA Power Networks is reporting outages , with 1000 properties without power in towns in the Adelaide Hills and about 900 in the Evanston area and surrounds.
Some of the outages are planned maintenance, but most are from damage to equipment.
A severe weather warning has been issued today for people in the Flinders, Mid North and parts of the Eastern Eyre Peninsula, North West Pastoral and North East Pastoral districts.
The Bureau of Meteorology has cancelled a warning for the West Coast, Lower Eyre Peninsula, Yorke Peninsula and Kangaroo Island districts.
It says the low-pressure system near Kangaroo Island is now weakening as it moves north-eastwards.
Wind gusts in excess of 90km/h are possible over the warning area, mostly associated with showers. Gusts are expected to weaken to below 90km/h in the next two-to-three hours.
People in the warning areas should move their cars under cover and away from trees, secure loose items and stay indoors while conditions are severe.
The weather bureau is predicting rainy and windy weather in Adelaide today with a top of 13°.
WILD WEATHER ACROSS SA
— There were more than 8000 homes without power during the peak of the storm, with the majority of outages in Port Augusta.
— Phone and internet services were cut for 60,000 homes in South Australia’s Mid-North but are back on after being offline for three hours overnight.
— Damaging winds were recorded in several parts of the state, including gusts of 96km/h at Hindmarsh Island, 95km/h at Port Lincoln and 93km/h at Marree.
— Winds briefly reached gale-force at Port Augusta with gusts to 87km/h.
— The SES responded to dozens of call-outs, mainly for trees down in the Adelaide Hills. One house in Old Reynella was flooded, while a tree fell on Strathalbyn Rd in Flaxley but there were no major traffic problems.
— There were reports that Mount Bryan in the state’s mid-north received 1.5cm of snow but there was none reported in Mount Lofty.
